prompts:
Create landing page hero copy and CTAs for a productivity app called FocusFox. Audience: freelancers and indie consultants. Key value: blocks distractions, timeboxes work, and auto-tracks billable hours with lightweight invoicing. Tone: crisp, confident, and motivating. Please return:
- Headline (max 8 words)
- Subheadline (1–2 sentences)
- Primary CTA button text
- Secondary CTA link text
- Background visual suggestion (1 line)
Keep total under 80 words.

Draft a hero section with CTA for Ripple Wash, a plastic-free, plant-based laundry detergent subscription. Value props: zero-waste refills, powerful clean, delivered monthly; carbon-neutral shipping. Tone: warm, trustworthy, modern. Please include:
- Headline
- Subheadline (max 2 sentences)
- Primary CTA button (mention 14-day free trial)
- Secondary link (comparison page)
- Social proof line (e.g., “4.8/5 from 3,200+ reviews”)
Keep it under 100 words.

Could you write a minimal, accessible HTML contact form with fields for Name, Email, and Message? Please include proper <label> elements, use type="email" for the email field, mark all fields as required, and add a submit button. No CSS or JavaScript—just the HTML snippet, please.

Create a small React functional component called ContactForm with three controlled inputs: name, email, and message. Use HTML5 validation (required, type="email"), and on submit, preventDefault and console.log an object with the field values. No external libraries or styling. Keep it concise and return only the component code.

Build a minimal, self-contained newsletter signup form with client-side email validation. Requirements:
- Plain HTML + a few lines of vanilla JS (no frameworks).
- Validate the email field on input and on submit; show a red inline error under the field when invalid.
- Disable the Subscribe button until the email is valid.
- On successful submit, prevent actual navigation and show a short 'Thanks for subscribing!' message.
Return a single HTML snippet with embedded JS/CSS only, no extra explanation.

Please review the login form markup below and suggest concise improvements for accessibility and usability. Focus on labels, input types, keyboard navigation, error messaging, and mobile autofill. Keep it to at most 6 bullet points and avoid code. HTML:
Remember me Forgot?

Help me write microcopy for a registration form. Fields: First name, Last name, Email, Password, Confirm password. Include: labels, placeholder (optional), short helper text, and a single clear error message for each field. Also provide the primary button text, a secondary link to “Sign in”, and the consent checkbox text referencing Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Keep each line under 60 characters. Return as a simple list with one line per item.

Could you write a very concise HTML snippet (no external libraries) that shows a responsive product listing grid with cards for a small plant shop? Include just the grid container and two example product cards. Each card should have an image, plant name, price, a one-line description, and an “Add to cart” button. Make it 2 columns on desktop and 1 column on mobile using minimal inline CSS. Please keep the entire snippet under 30 lines.

I’m designing a product listing grid with cards for a grocery app. Briefly describe the grid layout (how many columns on mobile/tablet/desktop in 2–3 sentences) and the essential card sections. Then provide: (1) a tiny CSS Grid rule set (no more than 6 lines) to achieve it, and (2) a sample JSON array of 4 products with fields: id, name, price, unit, thumbnailUrl, rating, isOnSale, and inStock.

I'm designing a portfolio gallery page with image thumbnails that open to a larger view. Can you give me best-practice guidance on thumbnail dimensions/aspect ratios, lazy-loading, hover/focus states, and accessible alt text/labels? Keep it to concise bullet points, and if you include any CSS, cap it at 8–10 lines.

I need a compact data model to drive a portfolio gallery with image thumbnails. Each item should include: id, title, short description, thumbnail URL, full image URL, width, height, category tags, and an optional external link. Please provide a small JSON example with 3 items and a one-sentence note on how it would be used to render the thumbnails.

Design a minimal, mobile‑first blog post template with a right sidebar. Constraints: single HTML file (no external CSS/JS), <= 90 lines total, use CSS Grid; below 768px the sidebar should stack under the article. Main content should include: title, date, reading time, hero image placeholder, body, tags, and prev/next links. Sidebar should include: author bio box, table of contents placeholder, a newsletter signup form (dummy action), and a short related posts list. Please add a skip link and appropriate ARIA landmarks, use neutral accessible colors, and mark editable areas with TODO comments.

Please write a compact Markdown blog post template that includes a clearly marked Sidebar section (since my generator doesn’t natively support sidebars). Start with YAML front matter (title, date, tags, description, hero_image). In the body, include placeholders for: intro, table of contents marker, sections with H2s, a key takeaways list, and a callout. After the main content, add a Sidebar block (demarcated with HTML comments) that contains placeholders for an author card, newsletter blurb, and related links. Keep the entire template under 60 lines and avoid generator‑specific syntax beyond YAML.

Write a concise pricing plans comparison section for our project management tool, SprintFlow. Plans and details:
- Starter: $12/user/mo monthly or $10/user/mo billed annually; up to 10 users; 5 projects; 10 GB storage; email support; 50 automations/mo; no SSO; no audit logs.
- Team: $25/user/mo monthly or $20/user/mo billed annually; up to 100 users; unlimited projects; 100 GB storage; priority chat support; 2,000 automations/mo; guest access; custom fields; no SSO.
- Business: $45/user/mo monthly or $40/user/mo billed annually; unlimited users; unlimited projects; 1 TB storage; 24/7 support; 10,000 automations/mo; SSO/SAML; audit logs; custom roles.
Deliver: a headline, a 1–2 sentence intro, compact bullet comparisons (3–5 bullets per plan), and a one-line recommendation on who each plan fits. Mention the 14-day free trial and that annual billing saves money. Keep it under 170 words.

Can you draft a short pricing comparison section for my fitness app, PulseFit? Plans:
- Free ($0): 3 workout plans, basic tracking, community access, ads, no offline.
- Plus ($7.99/mo or $59.99/yr): unlimited plans, offline downloads, Apple Health/Google Fit sync, no ads, custom goals, email support.
- Pro ($19.99/mo or $119.99/yr): everything in Plus, 1:1 coach messaging (2 replies/day), form analysis via video, advanced analytics, priority support.
Please include a clear headline, a one-sentence subhead, 4–6 bullets per plan, a note on annual savings (e.g., 'Save 37% annually' for Plus, 'Save 50%+' if applicable), and a simple CTA per plan like 'Get started' or 'Try Pro'. Keep it punchy—under 150 words.

Create an FAQ section for a landing page of a weekly meal kit delivery startup called FreshFork. Use HTML5 <details> and <summary> tags for collapsible items so each question can expand/collapse. Include exactly 5 FAQs. Keep each answer to 1–2 sentences. Cover: delivery areas, dietary options (vegan/gluten-free), pricing & billing, skipping a week/canceling, and packaging/recycling. Return only the HTML snippet.

Can you draft a compact FAQ for our university’s undergraduate admissions page in pure JSON for a React Accordion? Include 5 items with keys: id (slug), question, and answer. Keep each answer under 50 words and avoid line breaks. Topics: application deadlines, required tests, financial aid, transfer credits, and international applicants. Reply with JSON only.

Create a simple responsive navigation bar with a dropdown menu for 'Services'. Requirements:
- Pure HTML/CSS + a few lines of vanilla JS
- Click to open/close (no hover), and close when clicking outside
- Accessible: include appropriate ARIA roles/attributes
- Mobile-friendly: collapsible menu via a hamburger button
Please provide a concise example (no frameworks).

I'm using Bootstrap 5.3. How can I add a 'Products' dropdown in the navbar that's right-aligned, with a caret, opening on click? Please show the minimal navbar markup with the correct classes/data attributes to make it work.

Please write a minimal, responsive footer (keep it under ~35 lines total) that includes: 1) my name “Jane Lopez” and © 2025, 2) social links with inline SVG icons for GitHub, LinkedIn, and X (Twitter), using these URLs: GitHub: https://github.com/janelopez, LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/janelopez, X: https://x.com/jane_codes. Use accessible aria-labels and visible focus styles, and add a simple hover color change via CSS variables. No external libraries or icon CDNs. Return a single HTML snippet with a <style> block.

I need a tiny footer for my bakery website “Sweet Crumbs”. Provide a single HTML snippet (no external CSS; minimal inline styles) that shows our address and phone plus a ‘Follow us’ row with text+emoji links to Instagram and Facebook. Open links in a new tab and include rel attributes. Details: Address: 123 Maple Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11215; Phone: (718) 555-0198; Instagram: https://instagram.com/sweetcrumbsnyc; Facebook: https://facebook.com/sweetcrumbsnyc. Keep it under 15 lines.

Create a data table with sortable columns from the following employee roster. Return a markdown table with a header row only (no extra text). Columns: Name, Department, Role, Location, Start_Date (YYYY-MM-DD), Salary_USD (integer with no symbols or commas). This will be rendered in an app that supports sorting by clicking column headers. Initially sort by Department (A–Z), then Salary_USD (high to low).

Data:
- Alice Nguyen | Engineering | Backend Engineer | Seattle | 2019-04-15 | 135000
- Ben Ortiz | Sales | Account Executive | Austin | 2021-01-04 | 95000
- Carla Rossi | Marketing | Content Strategist | New York | 2018-09-10 | 88000
- Deepak Sharma | Engineering | DevOps Engineer | Remote | 2020-06-22 | 128000
- Elena Petrova | Product | Product Manager | San Francisco | 2017-11-06 | 150000
- Farah Khan | Design | UX Designer | Chicago | 2022-03-28 | 102000
- George Li | Finance | Financial Analyst | New York | 2019-07-01 | 110000
- Hana Suzuki | Engineering | Frontend Engineer | San Francisco | 2020-02-17 | 132000
- Ivan Popov | Support | Customer Support Lead | Remote | 2016-05-09 | 85000
- Julia Martins | HR | People Operations | Los Angeles | 2021-10-18 | 92000

Can you put the following smartphone specs into a tidy, sortable table? Use a markdown table with only the header and rows (no commentary). Columns: Model, Release_Year, Price_USD, Battery_mAh, Screen_in, Weight_g, IP_Rating, FiveG (Yes/No). Keep number fields purely numeric so sorting works. Sort initially by Price_USD ascending.

Models:
- Apple iPhone 14 | 2022 | 799 | 3279 | 6.1 | 172 | IP68 | Yes
- Apple iPhone 14 Pro | 2022 | 999 | 3200 | 6.1 | 206 | IP68 | Yes
- Samsung Galaxy S23 | 2023 | 799 | 3900 | 6.1 | 168 | IP68 | Yes
- Google Pixel 7 | 2022 | 599 | 4355 | 6.3 | 197 | IP68 | Yes
- OnePlus 11 | 2023 | 699 | 5000 | 6.7 | 205 | IP64 | Yes
- Samsung Galaxy A54 | 2023 | 449 | 5000 | 6.4 | 202 | IP67 | Yes
- Motorola Moto G Power (2023) | 2023 | 299 | 5000 | 6.5 | 185 | IP52 | Yes
- Apple iPhone SE (2022) | 2022 | 429 | 2018 | 4.7 | 144 | IP67 | Yes

Please update my to-do list. Current list:
- Buy groceries
- Call the dentist
- Submit the expense report

Add:
- Book train tickets to Boston for Dec 12
- Practice the presentation for Monday

Delete:
- Call the dentist

Return the updated list as a simple bullet list.

I keep my to-do list in JSON. Current list: ["Pay electricity bill", "Wash car", "Renew passport (expires May 2026)"]. Please add "Schedule eye exam" and "Email Mia about the volunteer event", and remove "Wash car". Reply with the updated JSON array only.
On a basic calculator, if you press: AC, 9, 0, 0, /, 3, 0, =, what number would be shown on the display?
Compute the result of this calculator key sequence and reply with only the final number: AC -> 1 -> 2 -> 5 -> / -> 5 -> = -> * -> 4 -> =

Can you provide a minimal, accessible modal dialog that opens when a button is clicked and closes on Esc, clicking the X, or clicking the backdrop? Please use plain HTML/CSS/vanilla JS, include basic focus trapping, and keep the code concise.

Design microcopy for a tab bar in a personal finance app. Tabs: Overview, Transactions, Insights, Settings. For each tab, provide: a short label (<=12 chars) and a one-sentence tooltip (<=90 chars). Also state which tab should be the default on first open and give a one-sentence rule for when to show a numeric badge. Keep the answer to 6–8 sentences.

Outline the minimal ARIA pattern for a tabbed interface with four tabs: Overview, Specs, Reviews, FAQ. Please list the required roles/attributes and the expected keyboard interactions (Left/Right, Home/End, Tab). Then include a compact HTML-only example showing the structure with one tab selected and its panel visible. Keep the code to about 15 lines and the explanation to a short paragraph.

Show the following pipeline stages as ASCII progress bars (width 30), using # for filled and - for empty, and append the percentage in parentheses. Stages:
- Build: 100%
- Unit tests: 65%
- Integration tests: 20%
- Deploy: 0%
Also add a final line with 'Overall:' and a single bar showing the simple average across stages. Plain text only.

Make a compact text status board for my home packing progress. For each room, render a 20-character progress bar using █ and ·, then the percent, and an icon (✅ for 100%, ⏳ for 1–99%, ⬜ for 0%):
- Kitchen: 80%
- Bedroom: 25%
- Living Room: 60%
- Bathroom: 100%
Put each room on its own line.

Run a multi-step bug report wizard for my team’s web app, Acme CRM. Ask one question at a time and wait for my answer before proceeding. Cover: short title, affected feature/module, environment (OS, browser/version), account/role, steps to reproduce, expected vs. actual results, frequency, screenshots/logs (placeholder), severity/impact, and any temporary workaround. Validate inputs briefly and offer 2–4 example choices where relevant. Support commands: [back], [skip], [cancel]. At the end, present a concise bug report in a clean template (max 250 words). Start with the first question.

I want help choosing and planning a 3-day weekend getaway using a step-by-step wizard. Ask one question at a time about: origin (Austin, TX), dates (late January, flexible), flight duration tolerance, weather preference, interests (food, museums, nature, nightlife), budget (~$900 total), and lodging type. Give 3–5 options plus “other” where possible, and let me type [back], [skip], or [cancel]. When I’m done, propose two itinerary options (morning/afternoon/evening each day) with a rough total cost range and 2–3 packing tips. Keep the final summary under 180 words. Let’s begin with dates.

Create a minimal, self-contained HTML file that shows a search bar above a static list of 10 movie titles. As the user types, filter the list with a case-insensitive substring match; when empty, show all titles. Use only plain HTML/CSS/JS (no frameworks) and keep the code as short as reasonably possible.

In React, write a small functional component called SearchContacts that renders a text input and filters a hardcoded array of 8 contacts (each with name and email). Show results as "Name — email" lines, filtering by case-insensitive substring match on either field. No API calls or effects—just client-side filtering. Provide only the component code.

Can you give me a minimal, dependency-free HTML + JS snippet for a countdown timer widget that: (1) counts down to Dec 31, 2025 23:59:59 local time, (2) displays as DD:HH:MM:SS, (3) has Start, Pause, and Reset buttons, and (4) announces 'Time is up!' for screen readers when it hits zero? Please keep the JS around 30–40 lines and briefly note any aria attributes I should include.

I'm adding a countdown timer widget to a product-launch landing page. In 5–7 bullet points, recommend the key UI/UX details: copy for labels, formatting (e.g., days vs hours), accessibility (live regions, color contrast), timezone messaging, and what happens when the timer hits zero. Keep it concise.
Write a one-sentence cookie consent banner for an EU e‑commerce site. Keep it under 18 words, in plain English, and include button labels: Accept all, Reject non‑essential, Manage choices.

Please rewrite this cookie consent banner for California (CPRA/CCPA) users to be clearer and more transparent. Keep the main sentence under 30 words, and provide button/link labels for: Accept all, Reject non‑essential, Manage preferences, Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Information. Current text: 'We use cookies to personalize content and ads, to provide social media features and to analyze our traffic. By using our site, you consent to cookies.'

Design a clean 404 error page layout for a B2B SaaS site. Context: brand is “Nimbus,” tone is calm/reassuring, primary #0F62FE, text #111827, background #F9FAFB, system font (Inter/Segoe/Helvetica), iconography allowed. Please outline:
- Section-by-section layout (hero, explanation, primary CTA, secondary links)
- Suggested microcopy (headline, 1–2 sentence explainer, CTA labels)
- Visual hierarchy, alignment, and spacing guidance
- One subtle micro-interaction idea
Keep it concise (<=150 words).

Create a playful 404 page layout for SnackBox, a colorful DTC snacks shop. Requirements:
- Elements: top nav/logo, breadcrumb, hero with illustration placeholder, witty headline, short explainer, site search bar, “Continue shopping” primary CTA, “Go home” secondary, and a 4-card “Popular snacks” module
- Color hints: coral #FF6F61, teal #00A8A8, banana #FFE066; use high-contrast accessible text
- Mobile-first; note one tweak for desktop
Return as a bullet list (max 10 bullets) with brief copy suggestions.

Provide a minimal, self-contained HTML/CSS example that demonstrates a responsive CSS Grid card layout: gap 12px; 1 column under 480px, 2 columns from 480–767px, 3 columns from 768–1023px, and 4 columns at 1024px and up. Each card should have a title and a short paragraph. No external libraries; keep the code brief.

Can you show a tiny demo of a responsive grid built with Flexbox that auto-wraps into as many columns as fit, with each card having a min-width of 220px (flex: 1 1 220px), a 16px gap, equal heights, and a subtle hover shadow? Include plain HTML and CSS only, with 6 sample items. Please keep it compact.

Create a contact-card directory from this staff roster. For each person, list: Full Name, Title, Department, Phone, Email, Office. Keep it compact and clearly separated between cards.

Roster:
- Dana Kim — Marketing Manager, Marketing — Phone: (555) 014-2389 — Email: dana.kim@acmeexample.com — Office: 3F-12
- Eli Turner — Software Engineer, Platform — Phone: (555) 016-4421 — Email: eli.turner@acmeexample.com — Office: 5E-07
- Priya Nair — HR Generalist, People Ops — Phone: (555) 010-9904 — Email: priya.nair@acmeexample.com — Office: 2C-03
- Miguel Santos — Sales Associate, Enterprise Sales — Phone: (555) 019-7711 — Email: miguel.santos@acmeexample.com — Office: 4D-22

Hey, can you put together a small contact-card directory for my wedding vendors? Please include: Vendor Type, Business Name, Main Contact, Phone, Email, Website, Notes. Make it easy to copy/paste.

Vendors:
1) Photographer — Shutter & Sage — Contact: Lena Brooks — Phone: 555-012-4456 — Email: lena@shutterandsage.example — Website: https://shutterandsage.example — Notes: Arrives 2 pm; Package A
2) Caterer — Maple Fork Catering — Contact: Jamal Ortiz — Phone: 555-018-2203 — Email: jamal@maplefork.example — Website: https://maplefork.example — Notes: Vegan options for 12
3) DJ — EchoMix DJs — Contact: Ravi Patel — Phone: 555-017-3030 — Email: ravi@echomix.example — Website: https://echomix.example — Notes: Setup at 5 pm; plays until 11 pm
4) Florist — Bloom & Bower — Contact: Sophie Tran — Phone: 555-013-7788 — Email: sophie@bloomandbower.example — Website: https://bloomandbower.example — Notes: Deliver by 1 pm; colors blush/green

Please draft a concise RSVP form I can paste into Google Forms for our company holiday party on Fri, Dec 13, 6–10 pm at The Skylight. Keep it to 7 questions max: attendance (Yes/No), full name, email, department (dropdown: Engineering, Sales, Marketing, Ops, HR, Other), guest/plus-one name (optional), entree choice (Beef/Chicken/Vegetarian/Vegan), and any dietary or accessibility needs (short text). Include a one-line friendly intro at the top, an RSVP deadline (Nov 29), and a brief confirmation message. Plain text only.

I need to submit my RSVP for the 'Tech for Good Gala.' Please turn the details below into compact 'Field: Answer' lines matching common RSVP forms. Details: Name: Jordan Lee; Email: jordan.lee@example.com; Attendance: Yes; Plus-one: No; Organization: CodeBridge; Meal preference: Vegetarian; Dietary restrictions: No peanuts; Accessibility needs: Wheelchair-accessible seating; Seating preference: With volunteer team; Notes: Happy to help with check-in.

Help me write the microcopy for a 5-star rating feedback widget in a project management web app. Please provide: (1) a main question (max 90 characters), (2) descriptive labels for each star (1–5) shown as tooltips, (3) placeholder text for an optional comment box (max 80 characters), and (4) three short follow-up prompts to show only if the user selects 1–2 stars, and three different follow-up prompts to show only if they select 4–5 stars (each max 90 characters). Keep the tone friendly and professional.

I’m building an accessible star rating widget (1–5 stars). Can you outline best practices for: (1) ARIA roles/attributes and labeling so screen readers announce the current rating and total, (2) keyboard interactions (Tab, Arrow keys, Enter, Escape) and focus order, and (3) error/validation messaging for an optional comment field tied to the rating? Please keep it concise, in bullet points, and include a minimal example snippet (10 lines or fewer) showing the recommended HTML attributes for the stars.

Can you give me a minimal example of a single-image upload form with live preview using only HTML and vanilla JS? Please keep the JS short (about 15–20 lines). Requirements: accept="image/*", show the selected file name, display a 150x150 thumbnail preview, and show a brief error message if the user chooses a non-image file.

I need a simple, responsive map placeholder for a Contact Us section. Please provide minimal HTML with embedded CSS that shows a gray box labeled 'Map Placeholder' and, directly below it, the address details for: Green Sparrow Cafe, 22 Elm Avenue, Boston, MA 02130, USA. Also include 'Phone: (617) 555-7820'. No JavaScript or external libraries; keep the code short and easy to drop into a page.

Create a compact SVG (400x240) that looks like a generic map placeholder: light gray background with a faint grid to imply streets, a red map pin centered, and the following address along the bottom: Hikari Dental Clinic, 3-12-4 Ginza, Chuo City, Tokyo 104-0061, Japan. Return only the SVG code.

Create a concise low‑fidelity mockup description for an e‑commerce admin dashboard. Include: header, left sidebar nav, and a 12‑column main grid. List and briefly describe 6–8 widgets: Today’s Revenue (KPI), Conversion Rate (sparkline), Top Products (table), Inventory Alerts (cards), Orders Over Time (area chart), Refund Requests (list), Traffic Sources (donut), System Health (status badges). Add 3 global filters (date range, channel, region). Recommend an above‑the‑fold arrangement for a 1440px‑wide layout with 24px gutters and a 72px header. End with a 2–3 sentence rationale. Keep it under 200 words.

Design a compact admin dashboard mockup for a DevOps team monitoring microservices. Provide: (1) a brief layout plan (header with env switcher/search, left nav, main grid with 3 rows), (2) a bullet list of exactly 7 widgets with one‑sentence each: Live Incidents, Error Rate by Service, Deployments Timeline, Latency Heatmap, Server CPU/RAM, Log Snippets, On‑call Roster, and (3) a minimal color theme (background, primary, success, warning, danger). Target a 1280×800 viewport; note any responsive stacking rules. Keep the response under 180 words.

Can you give me a minimal CSS Grid example for a web page with a vertical left sidebar (fixed 220px on desktop) and a main content area that fills the rest, with the sidebar stacking above the content below 640px width? Please include a tiny HTML snippet and keep the total code under 25 lines.

For an internal dashboard, I need a quick outline of how to structure a left sidebar navigation and a scrollable content area using Flexbox. No frameworks—just the basic HTML skeleton and 5–7 key CSS rules, plus one brief note on accessibility (keyboard focus). Keep it concise.

Help me add a dark/light theme toggle to this simple page. Requirements: - Respect prefers-color-scheme on first visit - A button toggles the theme - Persist the choice with localStorage - Use minimal CSS variables for colors Here’s my page markup: Theme Toggle Demo

Hello

Some text for contrast testing.

Please provide the minimal CSS and JS I should add (and tell me where to place them) to make this work.

In a SwiftUI app, how can I let users choose Light, Dark, or System theme and have that choice persist across launches? I’m looking for the smallest possible example using AppStorage, a Picker for the three options, and applying the selection app-wide (e.g., via preferredColorScheme in the App struct). Keep the code short and self-contained.
summary: Generating simple webpages with basic UI elements
